member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.ApplicationDescriptor
member.summary: Describes the product. The instances are spawned by the shell and populated with the assembly configuration and product edition parameters.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.IApplicationDescriptor
member.summary:
For a JetBrains .NET Platform based product, describes the static properties for that product. Being static, an Application Descriptor can be created without a Shell. It's used for getting static product info without a running product, eg for packing the assemblies for the setup package, or harvesting entities like registration attributes from all of the product assemblies. The AD can tell product properties, like name, version, build date, and URIs, and the list of product assemblies for various product configurations. A configuration is defined elsewhere, when starting the Shell over this AD, or specified for the setup package builder to tell which DLLs should go into setup. To start a Shell, create an AD of the specific type, give it enough context as needed, and call its overload of StartShell. A Shell cannot be created directly. A newly-created Shell remembers its underlying AD and uses it to get the list of the assemblies to run for the product. Even though you can create an AD directly, things Visual Studio integration package and setup package builder use autodiscovery to locate the AD because they're not product-specific and cannot know the exact AD class type. An defnies the Application Descriptor to be created.
Note: is all-static and the same throughout all the product runs, is bound to the single product run (but multiple shell runs, if needed), so it binds to cmdline and VS version, and the is for a single Shell run (in Visual Studio, our Shell can be started and stopped multiple times within the same VS run), and its is unique per run.

member.summary: Gets whether the universal value (string value ) is available on this set of items. Note that a universal product edition can be encountered in two cases: (1) On a product that does not support product editions ( is also Universal in this case), in which case it's the only allowed edition. (2) When there's no cached product edition for the installation, in which case you're not allowed to use this value and must change it to ASAP.

summary.para: Gets whether the installer is currently running in the VS-version-neutral mode.
The installer is conscequently run on the same data for each of VS versions supported, to produce VS-version-specific data for each VS.
Also it's run once in VS-version-neutral mode to collect the shared things (and avoid collecting them more than once, if included in version-specific runs).
When False, you can use the , , and attributes to learn the version. When True, the abovementioned properties cannot be access, and will throw.

member.summary: Maps a component instance to its initialization sequence number (this is intentionally non per-Type). Counted by exit from . member.name: F:JetBrains.ComponentModel.ComponentContainer.myComponentsSortedByType
member.summary: Lists values of sorted by their implementation type. This provides for the stable sorting order, as needed for serializing settings to get the same text representation of the same data repeatedly. Primary thread use only. Updated on each copy-on-write of . This seems to be better than having the SortedDictionary for storage (O(log(N)) retrieval instead of O(1) for hash-based dictionary).

member.name: F:JetBrains.ComponentModel.ComponentContainer.ComponentInstanceData.Component
member.summary: The component instance. Three phases: (1) Non-Initialized component, is non-Null by construction, is False. Components are first all created, then all inited, that's why this state exists. Getting this component on the Primary thread inits it, on any other thread fails. (2) Running component, is still non-Null, is True. Possibly, not all components enter this state. Main state of the component when the product is alive. Such a component can be gotten-instance without any restrictions. (3) Disposed component. is Null, is undefined. The datas are removed from the dictionary in bulk, because the dictionary is copy-on-write, and until the pack of components is removed, those that were disposed are in this state. Getting such a component fails.

member.summary: An interface for a component that has some settings and they should be saved whenever all of the application settings are being saved. // TODO: rework when we have a mature settings model.

summary.para: Tells the component container to reload the settings from the persistent media, deserialize them from the bag, and apply them to the components.
If a particular component has not been initialized yet, it will be called for / before its . Otherwise, those xml-related methods will be called on it for the second and so on time.
Tells the component container that it's about time to query the components of their settings, serialize them to the bag, and write that to the persistent media.
You must make sure this method is called on component containers in the end of the session. The component container will never save settings on its own.

summary.para: Invoked by the base implementation when it's time to load the XML Settings Bag from the permanent storage. Typically, in that's called from .

This logic (like, choosing the file) must be implemented by the inheritor. The inheritor might look for legacy settings files from previous versions if the normal settings file is missing and set to use them with components.
Call to submit the XML representation of the settings for a particular scope (see for details).
Invoked by the base implementation when it's time to save the XML Settings Bag to the permanent storage. Typically, in response to after the components are serialized into the bag.
This logic (like, choosing the file) must be implemented by the inheritor.

member.name: T:JetBrains.ComponentModel.XmlExternalizableComponentContainer.RetentionPolicySession
member.summary: Creates/checks the timestamps on the component settings. Tells whether the settings are allowed to be written.
member.remarks: If some component is missing from runtime for more than the specified retention period, the settings of such a component are discarded. Note that if the component is present but writes no settings, the old ones are removed at that moment, so this is not the case. The timestamping and checking are both done before the component is written. Missing timestamp means the data is coming fresh from the component.

param.para: This is used for the progress window title by the UI progress indicators.
The long form of the task caption should go to the of the 's .
Prepended with the product name automatically. Might be empty, in which case the product name will be used.

member.param: The task to execute.

param.name: cancelable
param.para: Whether the task could be canceled by the user, if the task progress indication provided by supports canceling.

The pattern is supported, which means that an is plugged on the task thread to throw a when called for a check with a False; such an exception is called by the task executor and converted into a False return value.

member.returns: Whether the task has completed execution (i.e. was not canceled). Note that even a task could be canceled by setting to False or throwing a or letting some other exception out of the task function.
member.remarks: If you would like to return any values from the , assign them to local variables within the closure.

This function converts between these representations.

member.param: The list of assembly configurations to be parsed as a product edition.

Whether other assembly configurations not controlled by the product edition are allowed in the collection. This is the case when the configuration of a running Shell is passed in, because it also might include public/internal, VS version and other configurations.
Called when an error is encountered. Throw the exception to have a never-returning-Null function, or pass in to handle failures softly.
member.returns: Product edition on success, a in case of a failure or for a product that does not support product editions.

member.name: T:JetBrains.ComponentModel.XmlExternalizationScope
member.summary: Defines the scopes for the externalizable components. The define the sets of isolated components that are serialized to separate storages. You may use one of the base values, or introduce your own ones as integers, as the string representations are never used. The scopes are normally not persisted, because they define a settings storage on serialization and are defined by the storage on deserialization.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.ShellLocks.AcquireReadLock
member.summary: Fetches read lock - the lock which is used to control read-access to ReSharper data (such as PSI, documents, etc.) and is obtained by threads that perform read-operations.
member.remarks:
Read lock cannot be acquired when the write lock is acquired by another thread and execution will be blocked until the write lock is released. You do not need to acquire read lock in the UI thread (since write operations cannot be performed in any thread different from the UI thread).
Use method to release read lock.
NOTE: the best way to hold read lock for a block of code is to use

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.ShellLocks.AcquireWriteLock
member.summary: Fetches write lock - the lock which is used to control write-access to ReSharper data (such as PSI, documents, etc.) and is obtained by threads that perform write-operations.
member.remarks:
Write lock cannot be acquired when the read lock is acquired by another thread and execution will be blocked until the read lock is released. Acquiring of the write lock is allowed only in the UI thread (and so you cannot perform any write operations from non-UI thread). Note that you do not have to obtain the write lock explicitly in most of cases. All low-level write methods (such as PSI or document modifications) obtain write lock automatically. You may need to obtain write lock if your subsystem (similar to PSI or documents) has its own data to be modified in write operations only.
Use method to release write lock.
NOTE: the best way to hold write lock for a block of code is to use

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.ExecuteOrQueue(System.String,System.Action)

summary.para: Executes an action on the primary thread in a guarded context.
If called on a foreign thread, executes the action asynchronously, like .

If called on the guarded thread, checks for reentrancy. If there are no guarded executions on the stack yet, executes the action immediately and synchronously, like . Otherwise, postpones the action for asynchronous execution, like does.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
member.returns: True if executed immediately, False if queued (-compatible behavior).

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.ExecuteOrQueueReadLock(System.String,System.Action)

summary.para: Executes an action on the primary thread in a guarded context.
If called on a foreign thread, executes the action asynchronously, like .

If called on the guarded thread, checks for reentrancy. If there are no guarded executions on the stack yet, executes the action immediately and synchronously. Otherwise, postpones the action for asynchronous execution, like does.
Takes a read lock.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
member.returns: True if executed immediately, False if queued (-compatible behavior).

summary.para: Checks that the activity is executed on the proper thread and is being guarded from reentrancy.

Does not break execution, just logs the failure — the common case of the failure is adding new guard-checks, in which case the features could go on functioning “as before” without breaking execution, but logging the failure.

summary.para: Queues the action to execute asynchronously on the primary thread in a guarded context, as soon as possible. Allows to reclaim the queueing and cancel the action from executing.
The reentrancy between guarded actions is prevented.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.QueueAtLong(System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

summary.para: Queues the action to execute once on the primary thread in a guarded context when the timeout elapses.
Handles intervals above , refuses to serve small intervals.
Returns a token that cancels the action execution. The token disposal is optional.
A is preventing reentrancy between the actions.
This is a low-throughput method and should not be used for delaying, cancelling and delaying again the events. For that purpose, use instead.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
A non-negative time interval.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.QueueBlinking(System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Int32,System.Action,System.Action)

summary.para: Queues two actions to execute asynchronously by turn on the primary thread in a guarded context at recurring intervals.
Returns a token that cancels the recurring action execution. This token must be eventually disposed of.
When the application gets inactive, the action is executed once, and then suspends until the application gets activated again.
A is preventing reentrancy between the actions.

member.param: The name for the task.
The first action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
The second action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
A non-negative time interval for each blink round.
The number of rounds.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.QueueGrouping(System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

summary.para: Creates and registers an event that groups multiple incoming signals within a time span and issues only one outgoing signal for them.
This allows to accomodate for external events firing at a high rate and execute the handler only when their activity suspends.
The object is thread-safe: the incoming event may fire on any thread, the outgoing activity always happens on the primary thread in a guarded context.
This function is free-threaded.

member.param: A name to identify the event.
The grouping interval. The incoming events are grouped until there's a pause of the length, and after that the outgoing event is fired. The interval must be not above .
Optional. The action for the outgoing event. This action will be executed on the primaty thread and under the . If you omit this action, advise the event on the return value.
member.returns: The event on which the incoming events can be fired. Must be disposed of.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.QueueReadLock(System.String,System.Action)

member.param: The name for the task.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.Invocator.QueueRecurring(System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

summary.para: Queues the action to execute asynchronously on the primary thread in a guarded context at recurring intervals. Can be used on the primary thread only.
Returns a token that cancels the recurring action execution. This token must be eventually disposed of.
When the application gets inactive, the action is executed once, and then suspends until the application gets activated again.
A is preventing reentrancy between the actions.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
A non-negative time interval.
